docs.title: Git Scanner
docs.text: Welcome to the Git Scanner documentation. This tool is designed to be a lightweight, dependency-free scanner for managing your git repositories.

docs.title: Features
docs.text:
• Recursively Scan: Finds all git repositories in a directory tree.
  • Status Check: Instantly see which repos are DIRTY (uncommitted changes) or have UNPUSHED commits.
  • Find Uninitialized Code: Identifies folders that contain code but have not been initialized as git repositories.
  • Zero Dependencies: The core tool is a single Python script using only the standard library.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text: • Python 3.6+: Pre-installed on most Linux/Mac systems and easily available on Windows.

docs.title: Download
docs.text:
Since this is a single-script tool, you can simply clone the repository or download scanner.py.

git clone https://github.com/your-username/git-scanner.git
cd git-scanner

docs.title: Optional: Alias
docs.text:
For easier access, you can add an alias to your shell profile (.bashrc or .zshrc):

alias gitscan="python3 /path/to/git-scanner/scanner.py"

docs.title: Basic Usage
docs.text:
Run the scanner by pointing it to a directory. If no directory is provided, it scans the current working directory.

python3 scanner.py [directory_path]

Example:

python3 scanner.py ~/projects

docs.title: CLI Arguments
docs.text: Argument Description path The root directory to scan. Defaults to . (Current Directory). --verbose Print more details during the scan. -h, --help Show the help message and exit.

docs.title: Understanding the Output
docs.text: The tool provides a clean summary of your repositories.

docs.title: Git Repositories
docs.text:
It lists found repositories with status icons:

  • [OK] CLEAN: No changes, everything up to date.
  • [*] DIRTY: You have uncommitted changes.
  • [*] UNPUSHED COMMITS: You have committed changes that haven't been pushed to the upstream branch.
  • [!] ERROR: Something went wrong checking status.

docs.title: Uninitialized Directories
docs.text:
Shows folders that contain source code (e.g., .py, .js, .c) but are not inside a git repository. This is useful for finding forgotten projects.
